news.title: How to Implement MetaMask SDK with Nextjs
news.subtitle: Learn how to integrate a 'Connect Wallet' button with MetaMask in Next.js. This tutorial covers setup, MetaMask SDK usage, and UI creation with ShadcnUI for blockchain interaction.

image.title: How to Implement MetaMask SDK with Nextjs Image

childMarkdownRemark.html:
In web3, a wallet refers to a digital application that allows users to interact with blockchain networks. Wallets serve as the bridge between users and the decentralized world of blockchain. Unlike traditional web applications that use email and password combinations or OAuth services for authentication, web3 apps authenticate users based on the ownership of a wallet and its associated private keys. The "Connect Wallet" button initiates this authentication process.

In this tutorial, we will implement a ‚ÄúConnect Wallet‚Äù button in a Next.js app that initiates the authentication process with MetaMask wallet.

Prerequisites:


  • Familiarity with Next.js and React.
  • Node.js and npm/yarn installed.
  • MetaMask extension installed in your browser.

While these are some prerequisites for this tutorial, the best way to learn is by getting started and learning along the way.

Setting up the Next.js project:


To set up a Next.js project, you need to have Node.js installed on your machine. Once Node.js is installed, you can create a new Next.js application by opening your terminal and running the following command:

npx create-next-app@latest

We will see the following prompts:

npx create-next-app@latest
‚úî What is your project named? ‚Ä¶ next-metamask-template
‚úî Would you like to use TypeScript? ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
‚úî Would you like to use ESLint? ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
‚úî Would you like to use Tailwind CSS? ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
‚úî Would you like to use `src/` directory? ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
‚úî Would you like to use App Router? (recommended) ‚Ä¶ No / Yes
‚úî Would you like to customize the default import alias (@/*)? ‚Ä¶ No / Yes

This command creates a new folder with the specified project name, sets up the initial Next.js structure, and installs all the necessary dependencies. Navigate to your folder.

cd next-metamask-template

and run the following command npm run dev, this command starts the Next.js application in development mode, and you can view your application by going to http://localhost:3000 in your web browser.

Creating the user interface


We will be adding a component library to our app. Let‚Äôs go ahead and install ShadcnUI.

npx shadcn-ui@latest init

We will see the following prompts to configure components.json:

Would you like to use TypeScript (recommended)? no / yes
Which style would you like to use? ‚Ä∫ Default
Which color would you like to use as base color? ‚Ä∫ Slate
Where is your global CSS file? ‚Ä∫ ‚Ä∫ app/globals.css
Do you want to use CSS variables for colors? ‚Ä∫ no / yes
Where is your tailwind.config.js located? ‚Ä∫ tailwind.config.js
Configure the import alias for components: ‚Ä∫ @/components
Configure the import alias for utils: ‚Ä∫ @/lib/utils
Are you using React Server Components? ‚Ä∫ no / yes

From the ShadcnUI component library, we will be using two components for this tutorial: Button and Popover.

We will also be using @metamask/sdk-react, you can read more about it from the MetaMask documentation.

Let‚Äôs Install the SDK:

npm i @metamask/sdk-react

We will be creating a new component called NavBar.tsx and adding the ‚ÄúConnect Wallet‚Äù button and SDK. Our component should look like this at first:

"use client";

import Link from "next/link";

import WalletIcon from "../public/icons/WalletIcon";

import { Button } from "./ui/button";

import { useSDK, MetaMaskProvider } from "@metamask/sdk-react";
import { formatAddress } from "../lib/utils";
import {
  Popover,
  PopoverTrigger,
  PopoverContent,
} from "@/components/ui/popover";

export const ConnectWalletButton = () => {
  const { sdk, connected, connecting, account } = useSDK();

  const connect = async () => {
    try {
      await sdk?.connect();
    } catch (err) {
      console.warn(`No accounts found`, err);
    }
  };

  const disconnect = () => {
    if (sdk) {
      sdk.terminate();
    }
  };

  return (
    <div className="relative">
      {connected ? (
        <Popover>
          <PopoverTrigger>
            <Button>{formatAddress(account)}</Button>
          </PopoverTrigger>
          <PopoverContent className="mt-2 w-44 bg-gray-100 border rounded-md shadow-lg right-0 z-10 top-10">
            <button
              onClick={disconnect}
              className="block w-full pl-2 pr-4 py-2 text-left text-[#F05252] hover:bg-gray-200"
            >
              Disconnect
            </button>
          </PopoverContent>
        </Popover>
      ) : (
        <Button disabled={connecting} onClick={connect}>
          <WalletIcon className="mr-2 h-4 w-4" /> Connect Wallet
        </Button>
      )}
    </div>
  );
};

Let‚Äôs see what we did here:

1. useSDK hook: Initially, our focus is on the useSDK hook, which allows access to the MetaMask SDK's functionalities. This hook provides an SDK object for interacting with MetaMask, a connected boolean to verify if the wallet is connected, a connecting boolean to check the connection status, and an account for accessing the user‚Äôs account address.

2. Connect and disconnect functions: The setup includes two key functions: connect and disconnect. The connect function is an asynchronous operation that tries to establish a connection with the MetaMask wallet using the SDK. Upon a successful connection, it updates the connected and account values from the useSDK hook. The disconnect function, on the other hand, is used to disconnect the wallet by invoking sdk.terminate().

3. UI elements: Our implementation incorporates two UI elements ‚Äì a button and a popover. The component's rendering changes based on the connection status. When connected, it displays a Popover component showing the formatted account address and an option to disconnect. If not connected, it shows a "Connect Wallet" button, which becomes disabled during an ongoing connection attempt.

Now Let‚Äôs add the code for the NavBar:

export const NavBar = () => {
  const host =
    typeof window !== "undefined" ? window.location.host : "defaultHost";

  const sdkOptions = {
    logging: { developerMode: false },
    checkInstallationImmediately: false,
    dappMetadata: {
      name: "Next-Metamask-Boilerplate",
      url: host, // using the host constant defined above
    },
  };

  return (
    <nav className="flex items-center justify-between max-w-screen-xl px-6 mx-auto py-7 rounded-xl">
      <Link href="/" className="flex gap-1 px-6">
        <span className="hidden text-2xl font-bold sm:block">
          <span className="text-gray-900">Template</span>
        </span>
      </Link>
      <div className="flex gap-4 px-6">
        <MetaMaskProvider debug={false} sdkOptions={sdkOptions}>
          <ConnectWalletButton />
        </MetaMaskProvider>
      </div>
    </nav>
  );
};

export default NavBar;

Let‚Äôs see what we did over here:

  1. Host variable: This variable determines the current window's host address for use in the SDK options. It includes a conditional check to verify if it's running in a browser environment.

  2. SDK options: These are the configuration options for the MetaMask SDK, setting preferences for logging and installation checks, and including metadata about the dapp.

  3. NavBar component: The NavBar features a link to the homepage and incorporates the ConnectWalletButton component. To provide the necessary context from the MetaMask SDK, it wraps the ConnectWalletButton with the MetaMaskProvider component, which is imported from @metamask/sdk-react.

  • Wallet Icon: To obtain the wallet icon, we used SVGR, a tool that converts SVG images into React components.

To prevent the full wallet address from occupying too much space in the NavBar, we'll make adjustments in the utils.ts file within the lib folder. This ensures the address is displayed in a more concise format.

import { clsx, type ClassValue } from "clsx";
import { twMerge } from "tailwind-merge";

export function cn(...inputs: ClassValue[]) {
  return twMerge(clsx(inputs));
}

Add the following lines:

export const formatBalance = (rawBalance: string) => {
  const balance = (parseInt(rawBalance) / 1000000000000000000).toFixed(2);
  return balance;
};

export const formatChainAsNum = (chainIdHex: string) => {
  const chainIdNum = parseInt(chainIdHex);
  return chainIdNum;
};

export const formatAddress = (addr: string | undefined) => {
  return `${addr?.substring(0, 8)}...`;
};

The above functions - formatBalance, formatChainAsNum, and formatAddress are designed to be imported and used throughout a dApp to consistently format and display blockchain data to the users.

On the NavBar Component we will import it like this:

import { formatAddress } from "../lib/utils";

And we used it here on the button:

<Button>{formatAddress(account)}</Button>

Now all that is left is to import NavBar.tsx into our layout.tsx component.

If we run our development server we will see the changes we have made to our app.

Conclusion


Metamask SDK is truly convenient and a game changer when it comes to building DApps. It enables users to easily connect to the MetaMask browser extension and MetaMask Mobile.

This was an intro to how to get started with MetaMask SDK but we can do a lot more with this and can use it on fullstack applications as well. You can find the code for this project on this repository here

I also reccommend checking the following resources:

  • MetaMask Docs: https://docs.metamask.io/wallet/how-to/connect/set-up-sdk/javascript/react/
  • EventSea : A Fullstack Events Dapp that also uses MetaMask SDK: https://github.com/Consensys/eventsea

Happy Building. üöÄ

nodes.title: 10 Things You Can Do with MetaMask Portfolio
nodes.subtitle: Whether you‚Äôre an OG or newbie, the Fox is here to make you more powerful in web3. Here are 10 things you can do today in MetaMask Portfolio.

image.title: 10 Things You Can Do with MetaMask Portfolio

childMarkdownRemark.html:
The MetaMask wallet has been around almost as long as web3 itself. Launched in 2016, the Fox has come a long way since then, guided by a mission to connect as many people around the world to the decentralized internet as possible. And we know connecting is just the start - much more than that MetaMask enables you to buy, sell, swap, bridge, stake, and beyond, and it all starts in Portfolio.

MetaMask Portfolio is where you get a clear, comprehensive view of your accounts and wallets across all networks. It‚Äôs also where your web3 journey begins. Whether you‚Äôve been using MetaMask for years or even minutes, here are ten things you can do in Portfolio right now:

Ten ways MetaMask Portfolio makes you powerful in web3


1. Manage your digital assets and track performance in the dashboard: Easily view and manage all your digital assets including Ethereum tokens (ERC-20) and non-fungible tokens (NFTs), all from a single, unified interface. Keep an eye on your portfolio's performance over time, with insights into asset distribution, historical transactions, and overall value trends. Remember you can view the balances of any public Ethereum address or ENS. You can also view which airdrops you‚Äôre eligible for by using the claim airdrop feature.

How to use the Dashboard on MetaMask Portfolio:




2. Do your taxes: Yes, that‚Äôs correct ‚Äì you can do your crypto taxes directly from Portfolio. All you have to do is connect your wallet and you‚Äôll receive 10% off your tax services with recommended providers like CoinTracker, CoinLedger, ZenLedger, Crypto Tax Calculator, and Koinly:


3. Connect to dapps and explore web3: Access and engage with all the dapps web3 has to offer directly through Portfolio: from decentralized finance (DeFi) platforms like Aave, Uniswap, and Renzo, gaming dapps such as HyperPlay to NFT marketplaces like OpenSea.

4. Swap tokens: Use the built-in swap feature to trade tokens directly within Portfolio, leveraging the best available rates across multiple decentralized exchanges (DEXs).



5. Connect to multiple networks: Beyond Ethereum, MetaMask supports various Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM)-compatible networks, allowing users to switch between networks like Binance Smart Chain, Polygon, Linea, and more.

6. Buy and sell cryptocurrency: Buy cryptocurrencies directly within MetaMask Portfolio using traditional payment methods such as bank transfers or credit cards, and through integrations with third-party providers like Paypal and Revoult. And if you‚Äôre ready to sell, Portfolio has you covered, simply connect your wallet and select your method to cash out.




7. Integrate with your hardware wallet: Enhance your security by connecting MetaMask to hardware wallets like Ledger or Trezor from Portfolio, combining the convenience of MetaMask with the robust security of cold storage.

8. Customize privacy settings: Adjust your privacy settings to your preference, including setting up a custom RPC for specific networks, managing connected sites, and reviewing permissions. Learn more about how to configure your privacy settings here.

9. Participate in staking: Stake your crypto directly through MetaMask Portfolio, participating in the decision-making processes of various protocols and earning rewards. In Portfolio, there are three options for staking, Validator, Pooled, and Liquid. The below tutorials show you how easy it is to start staking based on your preference.




10. Bridge tokens: Bridging tokens on MetaMask refers to the process of transferring digital assets or tokens from one blockchain network to another using MetaMask as the interface for the transaction. Bridging tokens is a powerful feature in Portfolio that enhances the interoperability between different blockchain networks, enabling users to leverage the unique advantages of each network.


Coming soon in Portfolio


Transfer assets from centralized exchanges (CEXs) like Coinbase and Binance directly to your MetaMask wallet, or between different accounts within MetaMask itself, with enhanced security and ease. Stay tuned for this feature coming soon in Portfolio.

MetaMask Portfolio not only simplifies the management of digital assets but also opens up a world of possibilities for users to explore and engage with the decentralized ecosystem, all while maintaining a high level of security and user control. Get started today.

nodes.title: MetaMask UI Update: Signature Redesign
nodes.subtitle: MetaMask Extension's new UI update makes reviewing signature requests simpler and clearer.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We‚Äôre excited to introduce our latest UI update for MetaMask Extension, aimed at improving the readability of signature requests.

For All Users: Whether you're new to MetaMask or a seasoned user, you'll notice a fresh, more visually pleasing look when receiving signature requests. This update makes it easier to understand and review the actions you're about to approve.

How It Works: Starting with v12.2 of the MetaMask Extension, you'll see the redesigned interface for Permit and Sign In With Ethereum signatures. Don't worry if you don't see changes right away‚Äîwe're rolling this out gradually to ensure a smooth transition.

In the coming months, we'll be extending this new UI to more signatures, transactions, and our Mobile app. Stay tuned for these updates!

To keep up with the latest on this rollout and other updates, follow us on Twitter @MetaMaskSupport and keep an eye on our Support Channel.

Want to Learn More? Dive deeper into the world of MetaMask signatures by checking out our support article.

Embrace clarity and enjoy peace of mind. Happy signing!

nodes.title: MetaMask UX Update: Improved Token Insights
nodes.subtitle: The new update provides a comprehensive understanding of your crypto assets with 24-hour percentage changes and detailed financial data per ERC20 token.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We are excited to introduce two important enhancements to our token management feature:

  1. 24-Hour percentage changes in token lists
  2. Detailed financial data in token details

Your token lists will now display 24-hour percentage changes, allowing you to quickly assess price trends directly in MetaMask. You can also access detailed financial data, including price charts and market cap information, when you click on your ERC20 tokens.

This is now available in MetaMask Extension and is coming soon to Mobile.

The 24-hour percentage change will be visible in the main asset list view, while detailed financial data can be found by clicking on the specific ERC20 tokens.

Whether you're a seasoned investor or new to crypto, having easy access to price trends and detailed financial information helps you manage your portfolio more effectively. You can learn more about it in our support article.

Stay tuned for further updates. Enjoy!
